name: cycle
content:
cycle

noun
 OPAL WOPAL S
 
/ˈsaɪkl/
 
/ˈsaɪkl/
jump to other results
  1. ​
    enlarge image
     
     a bicycle or motorcycle
    • He was riding his cycle home when he was hit by a lorry.
    • We went for a cycle ride on Sunday.
    • on a cycle Lots of people arrived in cars or on cycles.
    • by cycle They completed their journey by cycle.
    see also bikeTopics Transport by car or lorrya2, Sports: other sportsa2
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • motor
    • pedal
    verb + cycle
    • ride
    cycle + noun
    • ride
    • helmet
    • lane
    • …
    See full entry
  2. ​
     
    cycle (of something) the fact of a series of events being repeated many times, always in the same order
    • Every business goes through cycles.
    • cycle of something the cycle of the seasons
    • The argument is that reprisals simply perpetuate the cycle of violence.
    • They could not break the cycle of harvest failure, food shortage, price increase and misery.
    • in a cycle Front runners generally establish themselves early in the election cycle.
    • The percentage of companies being downgraded was typical for this point in the economic cycle.
    • different phases of the cell cycle
    see also carbon cycle, life cycle, lunar cycle, nitrogen cycle, water cycle
    Extra Examples
    • Life is a natural cycle, just like the changing seasons.
    • Male and female adults mate, the female lays eggs, and the cycle begins all over again.
    • The European market is simply going through an economic cycle.
    • The number of young produced per breeding cycle varies from species to species.
    • This cycle of events continually repeats itself.
    • To complete the cycle, oxygen is necessary.
    • a diagram of the water cycle
    • at this point in the cycle
    • caught up in a vicious cycle of bingeing and dieting
    • part of the cycle of birth and death
    • the 76-year solar cycle
    • the annual cycle of church festivals
    • women with irregular menstrual cycles
    Topics Moneyb1, Biologyb1
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • annual
    • daily
    • monthly
    • …
    verb + cycle
    • follow
    • go through
    • complete
    • …
    cycle + verb
    • begin again
    • continue
    • repeat (itself)
    • …
    cycle + noun
    • length
    • time
    preposition
    • in a/​the cycle
    • per cycle
    phrases
    • a cycle of abuse, poverty, violence, etc.
    • part of the cycle (of something)
    See full entry
  3. ​a complete set or series, for example of movements in a machine
    • eight cycles per second
    • the rinse cycle (= in a washing machine)
    see also song cycleTopics Engineeringb2
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • annual
    • daily
    • monthly
    • …
    verb + cycle
    • follow
    • go through
    • complete
    • …
    cycle + verb
    • begin again
    • continue
    • repeat (itself)
    • …
    cycle + noun
    • length
    • time
    preposition
    • in a/​the cycle
    • per cycle
    phrases
    • a cycle of abuse, poverty, violence, etc.
    • part of the cycle (of something)
    See full entry
    4. Word Originlate Middle English: from Old French, from late Latin cyclus, from Greek kuklos ‘circle’.
See cycle in the Oxford Advanced American DictionarySee cycle in the Oxford Learner's Dictionary of Academic English

name: cycle
content:
cycle

verb
 
 
/ˈsaɪkl/
 
/ˈsaɪkl/
[intransitive] (especially British English)
Verb Forms
present simple I / you / we / they cycle
 
/ˈsaɪkl/
 
/ˈsaɪkl/
he / she / it cycles
 
/ˈsaɪklz/
 
/ˈsaɪklz/
past simple cycled
 
/ˈsaɪkld/
 
/ˈsaɪkld/
past participle cycled
 
/ˈsaɪkld/
 
/ˈsaɪkld/
-ing form cycling
 
/ˈsaɪklɪŋ/
 
/ˈsaɪklɪŋ/
jump to other results
  1. ​to ride a bicycle; to travel by bicycle
    • measures to encourage more people to cycle
    • + adv./prep. I usually cycle home through the park.
    • He cycles ten miles to and from work every day.
    compare bicycle, bikeTopics Sports: other sportsa2
    Word Originlate Middle English: from Old French, from late Latin cyclus, from Greek kuklos ‘circle’.
See cycle in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary

name: cycle lane
content:
cycle lane

noun
 
/ˈsaɪkl leɪn/
 
/ˈsaɪkl leɪn/
 (British English)
(North American English bicycle lane, informal bike lane)
jump to other results
  1. ​
    enlarge image
    a part of a road that only bicycles are allowed to use
    • Cars are not allowed in the cycle lanes.
    Topics Transport by car or lorryb2
Check pronunciation: cycle lane

name: cycle path
content:
cycle path

noun
 
/ˈsaɪkl pɑːθ/
 
/ˈsaɪkl pæθ/
(also cycle track
 
/ˈsaɪkl træk/
 
/ˈsaɪkl træk/
, cycleway
 
/ˈsaɪklweɪ/
 
/ˈsaɪklweɪ/
)
(British English)
jump to other results
  1. ​a path or track that only people on bicycles are allowed to use
    • If there are people walking on the cycle path, ring your bell to get their attention.
    • New links create a safe network of cycleways through central Sydney.
Check pronunciation: cycle path

name: life cycle
content:
life cycle

noun
 
/ˈlaɪf saɪkl/
 
/ˈlaɪf saɪkl/
jump to other results
  1. ​(biology) the series of forms into which a living thing changes as it develops
    • the life cycle of the butterfly
    Topics Biologyb2
  2. ​the period of time during which something, for example a product, is developed and used
See life cycle in the Oxford Advanced American DictionarySee life cycle in the Oxford Learner's Dictionary of Academic English
Check pronunciation: life cycle

name: lunar cycle
content:
lunar cycle

noun
 
/ˌluːnə ˈsaɪkl/
 
/ˌluːnər ˈsaɪkl/
 (astronomy)
jump to other results
  1. ​a period of 19 years, after which the new moon and full moon return to the same day of the yearTopics Timec2
See lunar cycle in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: lunar cycle

name: song cycle
content:
song cycle

noun
 
/ˈsɒŋ saɪkl/
 
/ˈsɔːŋ saɪkl/
jump to other results
  1. ​a musical work which consists of a set of related songs, usually with words by the same poet
See song cycle in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: song cycle
nearBys: Songs of Innocence and of Experience

name: carbon cycle
content:
carbon cycle

noun
 
/ˈkɑːbən saɪkl/
 
/ˈkɑːrbən saɪkl/
[usually singular]
jump to other results
  1. ​the processes by which carbon is changed from one form to another within the environment, for example in plants and when wood or oil is burned
See carbon cycle in the Oxford Advanced American DictionarySee carbon cycle in the Oxford Learner's Dictionary of Academic English
Check pronunciation: carbon cycle

name: cycle rickshaw
content:
cycle rickshaw

noun
 
/ˈsaɪkl rɪkʃɔː/
 
/ˈsaɪkl rɪkʃɔː/
(also cycle-rickshaw)
jump to other results
  1. ​a vehicle like a bicycle with three wheels, with a covered seat for passengers behind the driver, used especially in some Asian countriesTopics Transport by car or lorryc2
